data.name: Index of Learning Styles
data.description: Assesses preferences on four dimensions of learning style

questions.text: I understand something better after I
options: try it out.
think it through.

questions.text: I would rather be considered
options: realistic.
innovative.

questions.text: When I think about what I did yesterday, I am most likely to get
options: a picture.
words.

questions.text: I tend to
options: understand details of a subject but may be fuzzy about its overall structure.
understand the overall structure but may be fuzzy about details.

questions.text: When I am learning something new, it helps me to
options: talk about it.
think about it.

questions.text: If I were a teacher, I would rather teach a course
options: that deals with facts and real life situations.
that deals with ideas and theories.

questions.text: I prefer to get new information in
options: pictures, diagrams, graphs, or maps.
written directions or verbal information.

questions.text: Once I understand
options: all the parts, I understand the whole thing.
the whole thing, I see how the parts fit.

questions.text: In a study group working on difficult material, I am more likely to
options: jump in and contribute ideas.
sit back and listen.

questions.text: I find it easier
options: to learn facts.
to learn concepts.

questions.text: In a book with lots of pictures and charts, I am likely to
options: look over the pictures and charts carefully.
focus on the written text.

questions.text: When I solve math problems
options: I usually work my way to the solutions one step at a time.
I often just see the solutions but then have to struggle to figure out the steps to get to them.

questions.text: In classes I have taken
options: I have usually gotten to know many of the students.
I have rarely gotten to know many of the students.

questions.text: In reading nonfiction, I prefer
options: something that teaches me new facts or tells me how to do something.
something that gives me new ideas to think about.

questions.text: I like teachers
options: who put a lot of diagrams on the board.
who spend a lot of time explaining.

questions.text: When I'm analyzing a story or a novel
options: I think of the incidents and try to put them together to figure out the themes.
I just know what the themes are when I finish reading and then I have to go back and find the incidents that demonstrate them.

questions.text: When I start a homework problem, I am more likely to
options: start working on the solution immediately.
try to fully understand the problem first.

questions.text: I prefer the idea of
options: certainty.
theory.

questions.text: I remember best
options: what I see.
what I hear.

questions.text: It is more important to me that an instructor
options: lay out the material in clear sequential steps.
give me an overall picture and relate the material to other subjects.

questions.text: I prefer to study
options: in a study group.
alone.

questions.text: I am more likely to be considered
options: careful about the details of my work.
creative about how to do my work.

questions.text: When I get directions to a new place, I prefer
options: a map.
written instructions.

questions.text: I learn
options: at a fairly regular pace. If I study hard, I'll 'get it.'
in fits and starts. I'll be totally confused and then suddenly it all 'clicks.'

questions.text: I would rather first
options: try things out.
think about how I'm going to do it.

questions.text: When I am reading for enjoyment, I like writers to
options: clearly say what they mean.
say things in creative, interesting ways.

questions.text: When I see a diagram or sketch in class, I am most likely to remember
options: the picture.
what the instructor said about it.

questions.text: When considering a body of information, I am more likely to
options: focus on details and miss the big picture.
try to understand the big picture before getting into the details.

questions.text: I more easily remember
options: something I have done.
something I have thought a lot about.

questions.text: When I have to perform a task, I prefer to
options: master one way of doing it.
come up with new ways of doing it.

questions.text: When someone is showing me data, I prefer
options: charts or graphs.
text summarizing the results.

questions.text: When writing a paper, I am more likely to
options: work on (think about or write) the beginning of the paper and progress forward.
work on (think about or write) different parts of the paper and then order them.

questions.text: When I have to work on a group project, I first want to
options: have 'group brainstorming' where everyone contributes ideas.
brainstorm individually and then come together as a group to compare ideas.

questions.text: I consider it higher praise to call someone
options: sensible.
imaginative.

questions.text: When I meet people at a party, I am more likely to remember
options: what they looked like.
what they said about themselves.

questions.text: When I am learning a new subject, I prefer to
options: stay focused on that subject, learning as much about it as I can.
try to make connections between that subject and related subjects.

questions.text: I am more likely to be considered
options: outgoing.
reserved.

questions.text: I prefer courses that emphasize
options: concrete material (facts, data).
abstract material (concepts, theories).

questions.text: For entertainment, I would rather
options: watch television.
read a book.

questions.text: Some teachers start their lectures with an outline of what they will cover. Such outlines are
options: somewhat helpful to me.
very helpful to me.

questions.text: The idea of doing homework in groups, with one grade for the entire group,
options: appeals to me.
does not appeal to me.

questions.text: When I am doing long calculations,
options: I tend to repeat all my steps and check my work carefully.
I find checking my work tiresome and have to force myself to do it.

questions.text: I tend to picture places I have been
options: easily and fairly accurately.
with difficulty and without much detail.

questions.text: When solving problems in a group, I would be more likely to
options: think of the steps in the solution process.
think of possible consequences or applications of the solution in a wide range of areas.
